Article.ArticleTitle: Interactive effect of leaf age and ozone on mesophyll conductance in Siebold's beech.

AbstractText: Mesophyll conductance (G<sub>m</sub> ) is one of the most important factors determining photosynthesis. Tropospheric ozone (O<sub>3</sub> ) is known to accelerate leaf senescence and causes a decline of photosynthetic activity in leaves. However, the effects of age-related variation of O<sub>3</sub> on G<sub>m</sub> have not been well investigated, and we, therefore, analysed leaf gas exchange data in a free-air O<sub>3</sub> exposure experiment on Siebold's beech with two levels (ambient and elevated O<sub>3</sub> : 28 and 62 nmol mol<sup>-1</sup> as daylight average, respectively). In addition, we examined whether O<sub>3</sub> -induced changes on leaf morphology (leaf mass per area, leaf density and leaf thickness) may affect CO<sub>2</sub> diffusion inside leaves. We found that O<sub>3</sub> damaged the photosynthetic biochemistry progressively during the growing season. The G<sub>m</sub> was associated with a reduced photosynthesis in O<sub>3</sub> -fumigated Siebold's beech in August. The O<sub>3</sub> -induced reduction of G<sub>m</sub> was negatively correlated with leaf density, which was increased by elevated O<sub>3</sub> , suggesting that the reduction of G<sub>m</sub> was accompanied by changes in the physical structure of mesophyll cells. On the other hand, in October, the O<sub>3</sub> -induced decrease of G<sub>m</sub> was diminished because G<sub>m</sub> decreased due to leaf senescence regardless of O<sub>3</sub> treatment. The reduction of photosynthesis in senescent leaves after O<sub>3</sub> exposure was mainly due to a decrease of maximum carboxylation rate (V<sub>cmax</sub> ) and/or maximum electron transport rate (J<sub>max</sub> ) rather than diffusive limitations to CO<sub>2</sub> transport such as G<sub>m</sub> . A leaf age×O<sub>3</sub> interaction of photosynthetic response will be a key for modelling photosynthesis in O<sub>3</sub> -polluted environments.
